<!--

  and ensure your pull request has fulfilled all requirements outlined by the Gitcoin Core team.

  Please note that deleting or not properly filling those sections below may result in your PR being rejected.
-->

##### Description

<!-- A description of what this PR aims to solve -->

Add popover quick glance to bounty detail

##### Checklist

<!-- For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->

- [x] Read and conforms to the [contributor guidelines](https://docs.gitcoin.co/mk_contributors/)
- [x] Read and conforms to the [style guidelines](https://docs.gitcoin.co/mk_styleguide/)
- [x] Linter status: 100% pass
- [ ] Added relevant tests
- [x] Tests pass and code coverage has not decreased
- [x] Changes don't break existing behavior
- [x] Commit message follows [commit guidelines](https://docs.gitcoin.co/mk_contributors/#step-4-commit)
- [x] [Code documentation](https://docs.gitcoin.co/mk_contributors/#docstrings)
- [ ] Completed: Code review by core team and any requested changes

##### Affected core subsystem(s)

<!-- Provide affected core subsystem(s) (like doc, ui, crypto, etc). -->

##### Refers/Fixes

<!--
  Link to an issue if applicable. For example:
  If your PR fixes an issue  -> Fixes: #102, #103
  If your PR refers an issue -> Refs: #101
-->
Fixes #3699 

##### Testing and Sign-off

<!-- Why should the PR reviewer trust that this change doesn't break anything? How have you tested this change? -->

###### Contributor

- [x] Read and followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://docs.gitcoin.co/mk_contributors/)
- [x] Tested all changes **locally**
- [x] Verified existing functionality
- [x] Ran `make test` and everything passed!

###### Reviewer

- [ ] Affirm contributor guidelines have been followed and requested changes made
- [ ] CI tests and linting pass
- [ ] No conflicts (migrations, files, etc)
- [ ] Regression tested against staging or local deployment

###### Funder

- [ ] Validated requested changes were made to specification
- [ ] Bounty payout released to the contributor

fields.title: Fee Discount Codes

payload.title: Fee Discount Codes

metadata.issueDescription:
### User Story

[comment]: # (As a <user type>, I want to <task> so that <goal>.)
As a Gitcoin team member I want send a code to funders that will reduce or eliminate their 10% fee when necessary.

### Why Is this Needed
For special events like hackathons where sponsorship is paid upfront in full, we want to waive the cost of posting bounties so funders aren't double-charged. For business development it is often useful to provide discounts to strategic partners trying out the system. If a funder experiences a bug and needs to re-post a bounty we don't want them to have to pay the fee again.

### Description
*Type*: Feature

### Current Behavior
10% fee cannot be waived or reduced. No coupon code field.

### Expected Behavior
Ability for Gitcoin team members to securely generate one-time use codes that can be pasted into the funder form to lower or eliminate the fees taken by Gitcoin. Ability to audit who got discounts and who created the discount.

### Definition of Done
Simple discount code generator, field for typing in a discount code, code to reduce the fee.

### Data Measurements
Increased long term retention of funders
Decreased operational effort on the Gitcoin Core team to manually track exceptions
Increased services revenue
Better UX for services clients

### Reach
All funders that fund an issue

### Impact
High Impact 

### Confidence 
100%

fields.title: profile: ability to enable users to update github username

payload.title: profile: ability to enable users to update github username

metadata.issueTitle: profile: ability to enable users to update github username
metadata.issueDescription:
##### Discuss

When an existing user updates his github username `foo` -> `bar`. 
He ends up losing his history on gitcoin.
Aka they'd be treated as a new user `bar` on Gitcoin and all their progress is lost

At the same time -> if a new user takes up the old username `foo`
They'd end up with the existing profile of `foo` on Gitcoin as opposed to getting a new one 

Should we build out a feature -> to help users migrate their profile if and when they update their github username ?
